description: [Status: stable] [Name: os-path-join] [Message: os.{module}.join() should be replaced by Path with / operator] What it does Checks for uses of os.path.join. Why is this bad? pathlib offers a high-level API for path manipulation, as compared to the lower-level API offered by os.path. When possible, using Path object methods such as Path.joinpath() or the / operator can improve readability over the os.path module's counterparts (e.g., os.path.join()). Examples import os os.path.join(os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, "folder"), "file.py") Use instead: from pathlib import Path Path(ROOT_PATH) / "folder" / "file.py" Known issues While using pathlib can improve the readability and type safety of your code, it can be less performant than the lower-level alternatives that work directly with strings, especially on older versions of Python.
